claims_to_validate.claim_text: Current system cannot automatically calculate salary based on actual working days, requiring manual interventions and separate tracking of overtime and unpaid leaves.

The system shows a discrepancy in daily wage formula calculation between leave policy and payroll settings. The payroll-side daily wage calculator takes precedence and overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave deductions. The greyed-out display in leave policy indicates this override is intentional.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

The system does not correctly account for 366 days in leap years (specifically 2024) when calculating End of Service (EOS) gratuity. This results in an incorrect total service period and gratuity amount calculation.

End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

The system's gratuity calculation involves complex logic for handling partial years of service, especially for periods above 5 years. The calculation differs from manual expectations by using specific day counting and leap year adjustment methodologies.
The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently account for February 29th in leap years, causing slight discrepancies in total service days and resulting gratuity amount
Platform calculates days worked slightly differently than manual calculation, adding an extra day (622 vs 623 days). This minor discrepancy impacts gratuity calculation precision.

System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. Users may misunderstand how daily wage is divided (31 vs 30 days) and challenge the resulting prorated salary amount.

The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

The system uses separate configurations for leave salary and salary proration daily wage calculations, causing different results. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to calculation mismatches.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The daily wage calculator fails to consistently prorate salaries for offboarded employees. When an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing, the system does not prorate the salary correctly and displays the full monthly amount instead of a prorated amount.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

Public holiday additions after leave request creation cause mismatches between HR and Payroll systems' daily wage calculations, resulting in incorrect salary deductions. The Time Off module does not send complete leave request details to the Payroll module at the time of calculation, causing data inconsistency when configuration changes occur mid-cycle.
The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations
The system displays incorrect daily rate remarks for February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave calculations. This results in deductions being calculated using gross salary instead of basic salary as configured in the policy.

The system displays the daily rate from the payroll processing month instead of the leave occurrence month, causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not match the month when leave was taken.
